fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Handbook of categorical algebra
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{borceux-1994, place = {Cambridge}, series = {Encyclopedia of Mathematics and its Applications}, title = {Handbook of Categorical Algebra}, publisher = {Cambridge University Press}, author = {Borceux, Francis}, year = {1994}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Handbook of Categorical Algebra is designed to give, in three volumes, a detailed account of what should be known by everybody working in, or using, category theory. As such it will be a unique reference. The volumes are written in sequence, with the first being essentially self-contained, and are accessible to graduate students with a good background in mathematics.

Volume 1, which is devoted to general concepts, can be used for advanced undergraduate courses on category theory. After introducing the terminology and proving the fundamental results concerning limits, adjoint functors and Kan extensions, the categories of fractions are studied in detail; special consideration is paid to the case of localizations. The remainder of the first volume studies various 'refinements' of the fundamental concepts of category and functor.

The second, which assumes familiarity with the material in the first, introduces important classes of categories that have played a fundamental role in the subject's development and applications. In addition, after several chapters discussing specific categories, the book develops all the major concepts concerning Benabou's ideas of fibred categories. There is ample material here for a graduate course in category theory, and the book should also serve as a reference for users.

Volume 3 begins with the essential aspects of the theory of locales, proceeding to a study in chapter 2 of the sheaves on a locale and on a topological space, in their various equivalent presentations: functors, etale maps or W-sets. Next, this situation is generalized to the case of sheaves on a site and the corresponding notion of Grothendieck topos is introduced. Chapter 4 relates the theory of Grothendieck toposes with that of accessible categories and sketches, by proving the existence of a classifying topos for all coherent theories.
Grp is regular.
Let \mathcal {V} be a monoidal category. A \mathcal {V}-category C, also called a category enriched in \mathcal {V}, consists of:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x, y\in C, an object C(x, y) of \mathcal {V}, called the hom-object;
for every triple of objects x, y, z\in C, a morphism C(y, z)\otimes C(x, y)\xrightarrow {\circ _{x,y,z}} C(x, z), called composition;
for evey object x\in C, a global element I\xrightarrow {1_x} C, called the identity.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must make the following associativity and unitality diagrams commute:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzcd} ( C(z, w)\otimes C(y,z))\otimes C(x, y) & & C(z, w)\otimes ( C(y,z)\otimes C(x, y)) \\ C(y, w)\otimes C(x, y) & C(x, y) & C(z, w)\otimes ( C(x, z)) \\ \arrow ["\alpha _{ C(z, w), C(y,z), C(x, y)}", from=1-1, to=1-3] \arrow ["\circ _{y, z, w}\otimes 1_{ C(x, y)}", from=1-1, to=2-1, swap] \arrow ["1_{ C(z, w)}\otimes \circ _{x, y, z}", from=1-3, to=2-3] \arrow ["\circ _{x, y, w}", from=2-1, to=2-2, swap] \arrow ["\circ _{x, z, w}", from=2-3, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

fr:title.text: Strong epis are regular in regular categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strong epis are regular in regular categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a regular category, a map is a strong epis iff it is a regular epi.
The backwards direction is always true. To show the forwards direction, factor f = mr for m a mono and e a regular epi, but note that m remains a strong epi, so is an isomorphism.
Regular categories have a (regular epi, mono) factorization system.

fr:title.text: Factorization systems are orthgonal iff strong

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Factorization systems are orthgonal iff strong

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C have (L, R)-factorizations. Then L and R are the respective orthogonal classes if and only if (L, R) forms a (strong) factorization system.
Conversely, TODO.
An epimorphism is regular if it is a coequalizer. Dually, a monomorphism is regular if it is an equalizer.
A category is regular if:

fr:ul.fr:li: regular epimorphisms have pullbacks and their pullbacks are regular.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every regular epimorphism is strong.

An epimorphism is strong if it has the (necessarily strong) left lifting property against any monomorphism; dually, a monomorphism is strong if it has the right lifting property against any epimorphism.
An internal relation r\xhookrightarrow {(r_1, r_2)} x^2 is an equivalence relation or congruence if it is:

fr:ul.fr:li: reflexive, i.e. there is a map x\xrightarrow {s} r which is a section of both r_1 and r_2;
symmetric, i.e. there is a map r\xrightarrow {\sigma } r which exchanges r_1 and r_2;

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A relation in a category C on objects x and y is a monormorphism into the product x\times y; more generally, it consists of a pair of of jointly monic arrows r\xhookrightarrow {r_1} x, r\xhookrightarrow {r_2} y so that for any pair of parallel arrows z\xhookrightarrow {f, g} r, r_1g = r_1h and r_2g = r_2h implies g = h.
The kernel of a map f is the equalizer of f and the zero map, when this data exists. The cokernel is the coequalizer of f and the zero map.
Dually, f is epic if and only if its cokernel pair is 1_y.

Suppose f is monic; then for any pair of maps z\overset {g, h}{\rightrightarrows } x such that fg = fh, g = h, so that g satisfies the universal property of the pullback; it is the only map which does so, again since f is monic.
Conversely, suppose the square is a pullback; then given maps z\xrightarrow {g, h} x such that fg = fh, both g and h witness the universal property, so uniqueness implies g = h.

A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is initial if for every category E and D-shaped diagram D\xrightarrow {K} E, there is a bijection which takes limit cones L\xrightarrow {\lambda _d} Kd to limit cones L\xrightarrow {\lambda _{Fc}} KFc.
Dually, a functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is final under the same condition about colimits.
